sen.j: 寛助（かんじょ、天喜5年（1057年） － 天治2年1月15日 (旧暦)（1125年2月19日））は、平安時代後期の真言宗の僧。
sen.e: Kanjo (15th January 1057 - 19th February 1125) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

sen.e: He is also known as Jojuin Daisojo, Ben Daisojo and Ho Kanpaku.

sen.j: 仁和寺経範の室に入って密教を学び、性信入道親王（しょうしんにゅうどうしんのう）から灌頂を受けた。
sen.e: Kanjo entered the Buddhist priesthood under Tsunenori of Ninna-ji Temple and studied esoteric Buddhism before being consecrated by priest-Imperial Prince Shoshin.

sen.j: 白河天皇からの信任が厚く、1099年（康和元年）権律師に任じられて以降、遍照寺 (京都市)別当・仁和寺別当・東寺長者・東寺法務を歴任した。
sen.e: He was deeply trusted by Emperor Shirakawa and after being granted the rank of Gon Risshi in 1099 and was successively appointed as betto (administrator) of Hensho-ji Temple (Kyoto City), betto (administrator) of Ninna-ji Temple, choja (head priest) of To-ji Temple and homu (director) of To-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1113年（永久 (元号)元年）鳥羽天皇の病気平癒の修法の報償として、東寺結縁灌頂の小阿闍梨（こあじゃり）が僧綱に任じられる慣例のもとを築いた。
sen.e: In 1113 the custom that the Ko-Ajari (lower ranking high priest) ordained at To-ji Temple would become appointed to the Sogo (Office of Monastic Affairs) was established as thanks when Kanjo conducted a ritual that cured Emperor Toba's illness.

sen.e: After this he served as betto (administrator) of Koryu-ji Temple, Hossho-ji Temple and Todai-ji Temple, and ascended to the rank of Daisojo in 1121.
